journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Construction of a nonlinear dynamic characteristic model of pneumatic artificial rubber muscle manipulator using the magnetorheological (MR) brake

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Precision Mechanics, Chuo University, Tokyo, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Hiroki Tomori, Department of Precision Mechanics, Chuo University, 1-13-27 Kasuga, Bunkyou-ku, Tokyo 112-8551, Japan. Email: h_tomori@bio.mech.chuo-u.ac.jp

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on 12th International Conference on Electrorheological Fluids and Magnetorheological Suspensions - Part 2

abstract.p: An artificial rubber muscle as an actuator was paid attention in this study because the manipulator was found to be safe to human when it comes in contact with human. However, this actuator vibrates easily with a late response because of the applied air pressure. Then, the magnetorheological brake that uses the magnetorheological fluid with an early response is built into the joint and controls the vibration. In this article, we have grasped the dynamic characteristics of a manipulator by the construction of a model for improvement in the control performance of the magnetorheological brake. Furthermore, the simulation was performed using the model, and efficient braking of the magnetorheological brake was examined.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recently, there have been advances in the development of partner robots aimed at providing life support and medical treatment and care such as power assistance (Satoh et al., 2010). These robots are expected to be safe to human when these robots contact human.

Then, we developed the straight-fiber-type artificial muscle (Nickel et al., 1963) as actuators. It has a high contraction percentage and high contractive force, and this muscle has a longer lifetime compared with past McKibben-type rubber artificial muscle (Chou and Hannaford, 1994; Gavrilovic and Maric, 1969; Klute et al., 1999; Nakamura, 2006). Moreover, these artificial muscles are lightweight, have high output, and are flexible. Therefore, a manipulator using straight-fiber-type artificial muscles has a wider range of motion and rigid control than a manipulator using McKibben-type artificial muscle. However, because the artificial muscle is flexible, it vibrates when there is a high load.

Therefore, we are interested in the magnetorheological (MR) brake using MR fluid (Park et al., 2008). Its apparent viscosity can be changed very quickly (in milliseconds) by applying a magnetic field. Because a response of the MR brake is quicker than a response of the straight-fiber-type artificial muscle, we thought that the MR brake can suppress vibration of the manipulator’s arm. However, there are other types of brake, for example, mechanical brake or electrorheological (ER) brake, a response of the mechanical brake is slow, and the ER brake is heavy and is not suitable for downsizing. We developed a 1-degree-of-freedom (1-DOF) artificial muscle manipulator that applied the MR brake to a joint.

This manipulator has difficulty to control for a strong nonlinearity of the artificial muscle. Thus, we linearized static response of artificial muscle using a mechanical equilibrium model. However, we propose that the dynamic characteristic of the artificial muscle manipulator should be considered for vibration control using the MR brake. Therefore, in this article, we construct a dynamic characteristic model of the artificial muscle manipulator, and we simulated position control of the manipulator using the MR brakes.

sec.title: Straight-fiber-type artificial muscle
sec.p: The whole artificial muscle figure developed at our laboratory is shown in Figure 1. The form of this artificial muscle is tubular, and the material used is natural-rubber-latex liquid. Moreover, since its structure includes a carbon fiber layer in the direction of an axis, if air pressure is supplied to this artificial muscle, the rubber membrane will expand, but the fiber stops the growth in the direction of an axis, so that the membrane is mostly not extended. As a result, the muscle expands only in a radial direction and contracts in the direction of an axis. The contractile force at this time is used as an actuator. This artificial muscle is lightweight, has high output, and is flexible.

caption.p: Fiber double-layer type artificial muscle.

sec.title: MR brakes
sec.p: We focused on the MR brake as a way to apply the MR fluid to the joint. In this study, we used the MRB-2107-3 of the LORD Co as the MR braking equipment. The overall view and the diagrammatic illustration of the MRB-2107-3 are shown in Figure 2. This device generates friction on the surface of the disk as it changes in response to the magnetic field by arranging the MR fluid in the internal disk surroundings. It is possible to apply brakes to a rotation operation according to this mechanism. The MR brake has the following features:

list-item.p: Since torque density is high, it is small and produces a high output.
Since the structure is simple, it is strong.
The speed of the response is in units of several milliseconds.

caption.p: MR brake.
MR: magnetorheological.

sec.title: 1-DOF artificial muscle manipulator
sec.p: The overall view of the 1-DOF artificial muscle manipulator that was produced in this study is shown in Figure 3. Table 1 shows parameters of this manipulator. The artificial muscle manipulator is arranged in the form where two artificial muscles rival one another, and the contractile force of the artificial muscle is transmitted to the axis of rotation through the pulley. The MR brake is fixed to the first link side, and it can apply braking power to the axis of rotation. The manipulator is installed in the load cell to detect the load torque that hangs to the joint and the encoder to detect the joint angle.

caption.p: 1-DOF artificial muscle manipulator.
DOF: degree of freedom.
Parameters of the manipulator.

tr.td: Center of gravity of second link l’G (mm)
Inertia of second link I1 (kg m2)
Parallel number of artificial muscles np

sec.title: Outline of the manipulator model
sec.p: We built a manipulator model while considering the dynamic characteristics of artificial muscles. By building this manipulator model, we were able to approach against control from theory.

The schematic view of this manipulator model is shown in Figure 4. This model consists of three parts. The first part is a mechanical equilibrium model (Tomori and Nakamura, 2011) treating the static characteristic of an artificial muscle. It is made easy to use the artificial muscle by linearizing the relation of the amount of pressure, load, and contraction. The second part is a model (Tomori and Nakamura, 2011) containing the elements related to the dynamic characteristics of the air artificial muscle system, including a pressure valve. The third part is a manipulator’s load system model. These models were combined and considered as the manipulator model.

caption.p: A schematic representation of the manipulator model.

sec.title: Mechanical equilibrium model
sec.p: In this section, we describe the mechanical equilibrium model treating the static characteristics of an artificial muscle. Since this artificial muscle has high nonlinearity between the amount of contraction, contractile force, and pressure, it is difficult to control. For that reason, we used the mechanical equilibrium model as the control technique of an artificial muscle.

A form of the artificial muscle used in this study is shown in Figure 5, and the parameters of the artificial muscle and the artificial muscle manipulator are shown in Table 2. In Figure 5, φ0 expresses an angle of circumference and is decided by the amount of contraction x. Here, a subscript is used to distinguish between artificial muscles 1 and 2, which is not based on the artificial muscle, but uses i in a common equation for the two muscles. The mechanical equilibrium model of the artificial muscle was proposed previously (Tomori and Nakamura, 2011), and the expression of relations of the desirable amount of contraction xd, load F, and pressure P can be obtained in the case where the form of this artificial muscle is modeled as shown in Figure 5. Using this mechanical equilibrium model, linearization of the target angle in an artificial muscle manipulator and an output angle is attained.

caption.p: Shape model of artificial muscle viewed along the z-axis.
Parameters of the artificial muscle.

sec.p: First, the expression of relations of the contractile force F of an artificial muscle turns into equation (1) from this mechanical equilibrium model as follows
In addition, each function is as follows

where xd is the amount of contraction, α is the constant that approximates the relation between the amount of contraction and the diameter, l0 is the initial length, d0 is the initial diameter, K is the elastic coefficient, t is the thickness of the rubber, M is the coefficient of the fiber of artificial muscle, n is the number of fibers, b is the width of the fiber, ψi is the slack of wire, and rp is the radius of pulley.

Here, the comparison of characteristics of the artificial muscle obtained by the mechanical equilibrium model and the experiment is shown in Figure 6. From Figure 6, we see that the mechanical equilibrium model and the real characteristics are fully in agreement, and we can check the usefulness of this model. Therefore, we can calculate the applied pressure by a desirable amount of contraction and load and linearize relations of desirable angle and output angle by the feed-forward compensation.

caption.p: Comparison with theoretical curve and experimental results.

sec.p: Next, we applied the mechanical equilibrium model of this artificial muscle to the manipulator of a joint system. The schematic view of an artificial muscle manipulator is shown in Figure 7. This artificial muscle manipulator has a rivalry structure. Therefore, the internal pressures of an artificial muscle, P1 and P2, can be calculated from the joint rigidity, Kj, and the target angle, θd, by applying the mechanical equilibrium model to this manipulator. The expression of relations of the joint rigidity Kj, the target angle θd, and the internal pressures P1 and P2 is shown in the following equations
where τ is load torque. Figure 8 shows a block diagram of the control system using mechanical equilibrium model.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of joint manipulator.
Block diagram of the control system.

sec.title: Dynamic characteristics model
sec.p: In this section, the element related to the dynamic characteristics of these artificial muscles is extracted, and it is included in the model. As elements related to the dynamic characteristics of an artificial muscle, the speed response of a solenoid valve, the ease of passing of the air in an air tube, the pressure change in an artificial muscle, and the volume change in an artificial muscle are mentioned. We assume that the influence the lateness of air pressure propagation has on the manipulator can be grasped by building the model in consideration of these elements.

The flow chart of this model is shown in Figure 9. Each element performs based on the feedback. For this reason, there is a great deal of repetitious calculation, and it is difficult to use this model for real-time control as it is.

caption.p: Nonlinear model of the straight-fiber-type artificial muscle.

sec.title: Response of speed of the solenoid valve
sec.p: First, we consider the characteristics of the solenoid valve (ITV2000 from SMC Corporation of America) that controls the fixed pressure from a compressor. We obtained the response of the solenoid valve experimentally, and we concluded that the response was a second-order lag system with a dead time. The characteristics of this solenoid valve are shown in equation (9). The input variable of this transfer function is desirable pressure Pd, and the output variable is actual pressure response Pu. In equation (9), T1 = 0.025 (s), T2 = 0.025 (s), and Ld = 0.040 (s).

sec.title: Air pressure propagation in a pipeline
sec.p: Next, we examined the characteristics of the air tube that transmits the pressure from the solenoid valve to the artificial muscles. The whole system, which includes the air tube and the inside of the solenoid valve, is expressed by using the sonic impedance C according to JIS B8390 (2002). Thereby, when the internal pressures of the artificial muscle and solenoid valve are determined, the mass flow rate of the air, qm, which flows into the inside of the artificial muscle, is shown by equations (10) and (11). We determined the sonic impedance experimentally. T0 in the equation expresses the normal condition temperature (K), ρ0 expresses the normal condition densities (kg/m3), C expresses the sonic impedance (kg s/m3), Pu expresses the upstream side pressure (inside of the solenoid valve) (MPa), Tu expresses the air temperature (K), P expresses the downstream side pressure (inside of an artificial muscle) (MPa), γ expresses critical pressure ratio, and P/Pu expresses a critical pressure ratio.

sec.title: The pressure change in an artificial muscle
sec.p: Next, we modeled the pressure change inside the artificial muscle by inflow of the air from the tube. We assumed that the adiabatic change had occurred in the artificial muscle. Then, based on the principle of conservation of energy, we drew equation (12). Moreover, R in the equation expresses a gas constant (Pa m3 Kg−1 K−1), κ expresses a ratio of specific heat, and V expresses artificial muscle inner volume (m3).

sec.title: Generating contractile force of the artificial muscle
sec.p: The contractile force of artificial muscles F, is calculated based on pressure changes, as shown in the first part of section ‘Dynamic characteristics model’. Contractile force is searched for based on the pressure in the artificial muscle using the mechanical equilibrium model shown in section ‘Mechanical equilibrium model’ of chapter 3. The determination of the contractile force, F, of the artificial muscle is shown in the following equation. Note that G1, G2, and G3 are shown in equations (3) to (5), respectively. However, the current amount of contraction x is used here and not the desirable amount of contraction xd.

sec.title: Volume change in the artificial muscle
sec.p: We modeled the change of the volume capacity according to the contraction of the artificial muscle. First, the change in the form of the artificial muscle is that it becomes circular, as shown in Figure 5. The next equation is obtained when we assume S as a cross section at right angles to the x-axis
where φ is variable of integration.
In addition, the following equation is made by geometric relations

Then, the artificial muscle inner volume, V, is expressed with the following equation. Moreover, Figure 10 shows a comparison of this equation with the experimental value. In the experiment, to measure volume, we used water, which is an incompressible fluid

caption.p: Comparison of theoretical and experimental results of inner volume.

sec.title: Load system model of the arm
sec.p: The flow chart of the load system model is shown in Figure 11. We calculated the drive torque of the arm from contractive forces F1 and F2 of the rivaled artificial muscle as follows:

caption.p: The load system model of a manipulator arm.

sec.p: Next, the inertia moment of the arm, I1, and the inertia moment of the load, I2, added at the tip of the arm are calculated, and the sum total is set to I. The following equations consider the arm as a hollow cylinder, and the load at the tip of the arm as a pillar, where M1 is the mass of the first link, R1 is the outer diameter, r1 is the inner diameter, h1 is the length of the first link, M2 is the mass of load, R2 is the diameter of load, and h2 is the height of load.

In addition, the load torque by the load and the arm is calculated. The load torque, τl, depends on the rotation angle θ of the arm and is obtained by the following equation. Here, g is gravitational acceleration (m/s2).

Next, the brake torque to the arm by the MR brake is considered, as expressed in equation (23). The direction of the brake torque is reversed by the sign at the rotation angle speed of the arm, since the brake torque always resists the rotation of the arm. Here, c is a viscous coefficient and E is the voltage applied to this brake.

The angular acceleration of the arm is calculated from the kinetics of equation (25) by using the values of equations (18), (19), (22), and (23). In addition, the value of the torque fed back to the mechanical equilibrium model is calculated from equation (26)

sec.title: Examination of the effect of the MR brake
Control of the MR brake
sec.p: Until now, we inputted the brake torque value into the MR brake and had stopped rotation of an arm. However, the MR brake interferes with the arm, because the MR brake has very small viscosity coefficient. The MR brake continues outputting brake torque, without being dependent on the revolving speed. In this article, we propose the controller of the MR brake for the noninterference with the arm. The propositional technique of control of the MR brake is shown in Figure 12. In this propositional technique, the output torque of the MR brake depends on the rotary speed of the arm. In addition, apparent viscosity coefficient can be changed by control. By this control, the MR brake obtained output characteristics as shown in Figure 13. Two lines show the way of the rise in torque for the speed. The quadratic curve has a smaller interference in the low speed than a straight line.

caption.p: Controller of the MR brake.
MR: magnetorheological.
Output characteristics of the MR brake controlled by propositional technique.
MR: magnetorheological.

sec.title: Examination of the effect of the MR brake using the model
sec.p: We simulated raising load (8.33 N) to a desirable angle using a manipulator model. Figure 14 shows the simulation result without the MR brake. The simulation result by the conventional control is shown in Figure 15, and the simulation results by the propositional control are shown in Figure 16. Table 3 shows the numerical data of this model.

caption.p: The simulation result without the MR brake.
MR: magnetorheological.
Simulation results by the conventional control.
Simulation results by the propositional control: (a) the brake torque increases for rotary speed linearly and (b) the brake torque increases for rotary speed quadratically.
The numerical data of the model.

sec.p: From the results of simulations, the vibration of the arm was suppressed by the MR brake, and the stationary error of the angle response decreased by the propositional technique. We assume that the reduction in the stationary error is an effect of the MR brake, which was given the viscosity coefficient by the propositional controller. From Figure 16, the simulation result (a) caught the interference by the MR brake larger than the simulation result (b) in a transient state.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, we examined the effect of the MR brake by simulation and checked the reduction of vibration and stationary error by the MR brake. We believe our simulation results show effective control by the MR brake.

As future research, the control in which the MR brake does not interfere superfluously will be designed for flattering to the target angle of the arm. We also hope to further improve the rise time, and we will compare the simulation result by the model with the experimental result.

fn.p: This work was supported in part by the Institute of Science and Engineering, Chuo University.
